oai_dc:dc.dc:title: INFLUENCE OF HIGH-ANGLE WAVE INSTABILITY ON LARGE SCALE SHORELINE PROJECTIONS UNDER MEAN SEA LEVEL RISE. LLOBREGAT DELTA CASE STUDY.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Falques, Albert
Ribas, Francesca
Negre, Miquel
Lopez, Lucas
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In the context of mean sea-level rise, knowing the processes driving long term coastline evolution is an important concern for coastal management. One of such long-term processes is high-angle wave instability (hereinafter HAWI) than can occur on sandy coasts with a wave climate dominated by high-angle waves (with respect to the shore-normal). According to Ashton et al. (2001) this process leads to an anti-diffusive behavior on shoreline features. The theoretical characteristics of HAWI have been extensively investigated during the last two decades (see, for example, Falqu√©s et al., 2017, and references therein) but its experimental validation is still hardly achieved.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; sediment.96
